description: From Early Modern English conferre, from Middle French conférer, from Old French conferer, from Latin cōnferō. Compare Dutch confereren (“to confer”), German konferieren (“to confer”), Danish konferere (“to confer”), Swedish konferera (“to confer”).

verbs.description: confer (third-person singular simple present confers, present participle conferring, simple past and past participle conferred)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To grant as a possession; to bestow. [from 16th c.]
examples: The college has conferred an honorary degree upon the visiting Prime Minister.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To talk together, to consult, discuss; to deliberate. [from 16th c.]
examples: They were in a huddle, conferring about something.
The Newe Testament ... Conferred diligently with the Greke, and best approued translations.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To bring together; to collect, gather. [16th–17th c.]

examples: The closeness and compactness of the parts resting together doth much confer to the strength of the union.
